contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that the original hearers would be aware of when a large earthquake had affected the area. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: two years before the earthquake

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that Esau, from whom the people of Edom were descended, was the brother of Jacob, from whom the people of Israel were descended. Here “his brother” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “he pursued the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he pursued his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the fast runner will not escape from his enemies. Alternate translation: “the fast runner will be captured” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the fast runner will not escape

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that they should have obeyed him. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I have chosen only you from all the families of the earth, so you should have obeyed me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I have chosen only you from all the families of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that they did not obey God. Alternate translation: “But you did not obey me. Therefore I will punish you for all your sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore I will punish you for all your sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The purpose of sounding the trumpet is to warn people that enemies are about to attack the city. Alternate translation: “If someone blows the trumpet in the city to warn the people about an enemy attack” or “If the warning trumpet is blown in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: If a trumpet sounds in a city

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reason for trembling can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “tremble because they are afraid” or “be afraid of the enemy and tremble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “great confusion is in her” refers to people’s fear because of the fighting and rioting there. The word “confusion” can be translated with a verbal phrase to make this meaning explicit. Alternate translation: “how the people in Samaria riot” or “how the people in Samaria fight against one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: what great confusion is in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly who God was saying this to. Alternate translation: “Therefore, this is what the Lord Yahweh says to the people of Israel living in Samaria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore, this is what the Lord Yahweh says

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that the shepherd tries to rescue the whole animal. Alternate translation: “As the shepherd tries to rescue an animal from the lion’s mouth, but is able to save only two legs or a piece of an ear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: As the shepherd rescues out of the mouth of the lion two legs only, or a piece of an ear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh rebukes them for being proud about their offerings and sacrifices. They think that God should be pleased with them, but he is not. Alternate translation: “for this pleases you, you people of Israel. But it does not please me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for this pleases you, you people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that the people needed the rain. Alternate translation: “when there were still three months to the harvest and your crops needed the rain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: when there were still three months to the harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “a thousand” and “a hundred” refer to a thousand soldiers and a hundred soldiers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The city that went out with a thousand will have a hundred left

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The city that went out” represents the soldiers of that city going out. It can be stated clearly why they went out. Alternate translation: “The city out of which a thousand soldiers went to fight” or “The city that sent out a thousand soldiers to fight” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The city that went out with a thousand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “their” refers to the vineyards. This may imply that no one will make the wine, or even that there will not be enough good grapes to make wine. Alternate translation: “you will not drink the wine that is made from the grapes in your vineyards” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you will not drink their wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “turn aside the needy” represents telling the needy people to leave. It can be made clear why the needy were at the city gate. Alternate translation: “do not allow poor people to bring their cases to the judges in the city gate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: turn aside the needy in the city gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: City gates were where business transactions occurred and judgments were made, because city walls were thick enough to have gateways that produced cool shade from the hot sun Alternate translation: “in your courts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in the city gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that they drink a lot of wine because they drink it from a large bowl rather than a regular wine cup. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: drink wine from bowls

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Yahweh hates the fortresses because the people believed the fortresses would keep them safe. Alternate translation: “I hate the people of Israel because they trust in their fortresses, not in me, to protect them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I hate his fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This seems to imply that something terrible is happening, and these ten men go into the house to hide. Alternate translation: “if ten men are hiding inside of a house, they will all still die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: if there are ten men left in one house, they will all die

contextId.occurrenceNote: The meaning of this is not clear. It seems to imply that the one who asked the question is afraid the one answering will mention Yahweh’s name carelessly. If he does this, it may draw Yahweh’s attention to them, and he may kill them too. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then he will say, “Be quiet, for we must not mention Yahweh’s name.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies the Dead Sea in the south and the Mediterranean Sea in the west. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from sea to sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Yahweh is speaking about the pillars and foundations of a temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Strike the tops of the pillars so that the foundations will shake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “vault” refers to the sky which biblical writers described as being a dome over the earth. Alternate translation: “he sets the sky over the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: has established his vault over the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “comes” can be stated as “goes.” Alternate translation: “goes for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.quoteString: comes for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Tekoa” is the name of a town or village. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: in Tekoa

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hazael & Ben Hadad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place that means “valley of wickedness.” This could mean: (1) this is the name of an actual place in that region or (2) this is a metonym for Damascus or the surrounding region. Alternate translation: “the valley of wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Valley of Aven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a place that means “house of pleasure.” This could mean: (1) this is the name of an actual place in that region or (2) this is another metonym for Damascus or the surrounding region. Alternate translation: “the house of pleasure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Beth Eden

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a region from which the people of Aram originally came. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of places. See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]]
contextId.quoteString: Teman & Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city or town. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kerioth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is either the name of a place that we do not know, or it refers to Mount Hermon. Some modern versions interpret it in that way. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Harmon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of two false gods. The people had made images to represent them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sikkuth & Kaiwan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kalneh

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Lo Debar & Karnaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Amaziah

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person shaves his head to show that he is grieving. Alternate translation: “cause you all to shave your heads” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: have baldness on every head

contextId.occurrenceNote: People saw patterns in the stars in the sky and gave names to them. These are two of those patterns. Alternate translation: “the stars” or “the groups of stars” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: the Pleiades and Orion

contextId.occurrenceNote: a white substance made from the teeth and horns of large animals (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: ivory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sycamores are broad trees that grow up to 15 meters tall. Alternate translation: “fig trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: sycamore fig trees

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

God speaks through Amos using poetic language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated positively. Alternate translation: “Surely the Lord Yahweh will reveal … prophets before he does anything” or “So also, the Lord will punish people only if he has revealed his plan to his servants the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: Surely the Lord Yahweh will do nothing unless he reveals & prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “despise” is a strong word for “hate.” Together the two words emphasize the intensity of Yahweh’s hatred for their religious festivals. Alternate translation: “I hate your festivals very much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I hate, I despise your festivals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “king’s sanctuary” and “royal house” refer to the same place. Alternate translation: “this is where the national temple is, the place where the king worships” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: for it is the king’s sanctuary and a royal house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “they will call” is understood from the beginning of the sentence. Alternate translation: “they will call the mourners to wail” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the mourners to wail

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated with the understood information included. Alternate translation: “enemies will smash the little house to bits” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the little house to bits

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “your people” or “us” are understood. Alternate translation: “please forgive your people” or “please forgive us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: please forgive

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “and buy” are understood. Alternate translation: “buy the needy for a pair of sandals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the needy for a pair of sandals

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that the only son has died. Alternate translation: “like mourning for an only son who has died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: like mourning for an only son

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “hav sexual relations with the same girl” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: go in to the same girl

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration that is meant to express the ongoing nature of his wrath. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: his wrath lasted forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration. It describes how tall and strong the Amorite people were and compares them to the tallest and strongest trees in that region. Alternate translation: “who were tall and strong like great trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: whose height was like the height of cedars; he was strong as the oaks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses an exaggerated image of people fleeing to Sheol or heaven to try to escape being killed. Here “Sheol” and “heaven” are a merism that represents all places. Alternate translation: “Even if they were to flee to Sheol or to heaven, they would not be able to escape me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Though they dig into Sheol, there my hand will take them & hough they climb up to heaven, there I will bring them down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh gives an exaggerated image of the people fleeing to the top of mount Carmel or to the bottom of the sea to escape being killed. Here “top of Carmel” and “bottom of the sea” are a merism that represents all places. Alternate translation: “Even if they were to hide on the top of Carmel … Even if they tried to go the bottom sea, thinking that I could not see them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Though they hide on the top of Carmel & Though they are hidden from my sight in the bottom of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “in the days of” is an idiom and refers to the time when each king reigned. Alternate translation: “when Uzziah was king of Judah, and also when Jeroboam son of Joash was king of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the days of Uzziah king of Judah, and also in the days of Jeroboam son of Joash king of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of how Damascus treated Gilead as if they had threshed grain with iron tools or weapons. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they threshed Gilead with instruments of iron

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they refused to listen when the oppressed people said they were being treated unfairly (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they push the oppressed away

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Yahweh completely destroyed the Amorites is pictured as a tree being destroyed from top to bottom. Alternate translation: “Yet I destroyed them completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Yet I destroyed his fruit above and his roots below

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “establish justice” represents making sure that justice is done. Alternate translation: “make sure that justice is done in the city gates” or “make sure that the judges make just decisions in the city gates” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: establish justice in the city gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eat bread” is an idiom that means to earn money or make a living for doing something. Alternate translation: “see if you can get the people there to pay you for prophesying” or “prophesy there and let them provide you with food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: there eat bread and prophesy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “they will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “from the face of the earth” means “completely.” Alternate translation: “I will completely destroy this kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will destroy it from the face of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would go to Bethel and Gilgal to make sacrifices to God, but they kept sinning anyway. God makes these commands to show that he is angry with them for doing these things. These commands can be expressed as statements. Alternate translation: “You go to Bethel to worship, but you sin. You go to Gilgal to worship, but you sin even more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Go to Bethel and sin, to Gilgal and multiply sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: God makes these commands in order to show the people that he is angry that even though they do these things, they continue to sin against him in other ways. These commands can be expressed as statements. Alternate translation: “You bring your sacrifices … every three days, but it does you no good.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: bring your sacrifices & every three days

contextId.occurrenceNote: God makes these commands in order to show the people that even though they do these things, he is angry because they continue to sin against him in other ways. Use the form in your language that shows that they will do these things no matter what Yahweh says, but these things will do them no good. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Offer a thanksgiving sacrifice & proclaim freewill offerings; announce them, for this pleases

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the most important men of this great nation.” Yahweh may be using irony to describe how these men think of themselves. Alternate translation: “the men who think they are the most important people in the best nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: the notable men of the best of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses two negatives here to emphasize that he would punish them. Alternate translation: “I will certainly punish those people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not turn away punishment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sea to sea” and “the north to the east” represent all of the land of Israel. Alternate translation: “They will wander here and there and search all over for the word of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: They will stagger from sea to sea; they will run from the north to the east to seek the word of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the voice of Yahweh as if it sounded like the roar of a lion or the roar of thunder. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will roar

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of his judgment against the house of Hazael as if it were a consuming fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send a fire into the house of Hazael

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the fortresses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour the fortresses of Ben Hadad

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “cut off” means either to destroy or to drive away, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “destroy the man” or “drive away the man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off the man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the fortresses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour her fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “cut off” means either to destroy or to drive away, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: “destroy the man” or “drive away the man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off the man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the fortresses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour her fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the palaces. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour the palaces of Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the palaces. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour the palaces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The fighting against the people of Ammon is spoken of as if it were a violent storm. Alternate translation: “and the fighting will be like a great storm” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: with a tempest in the day of the whirlwind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression here probably refers to worshiping false gods or idols. Alternate translation: “Their worship of idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Their lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping false gods is spoken of as if people were walking behind them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: go astray & walked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s judgment is spoken of as if it were a fire that was consuming the fortresses. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will devour the fortresses of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something terrible happening to a city is spoken of as if disaster overtakes it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: If disaster overtakes a city,

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the large houses will exist no more.” Here “vanish” represents being destroyed. Alternate translation: “the large houses will be destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the large houses will vanish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos speaks to the women of Israel who live in Samaria as if they were well-fed cows. Alternate translation: “you wealthy women who live in the mountains of Samaria, you who are like the well-fed cows of Bashan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you cows of Bashan, you who are in the mountain of Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hear “crush” is a metaphor that represents treating people badly. The phrase “the needy” refers to people who need help. Alternate translation: “you who treat needy people badly” or “you who hurt needy people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: you who crush the needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: A time in the future when bad things will happen to the people is spoken of as if those days will attack the people. The word “they” refers to their enemies. Alternate translation: “There will be a time when your enemies will take you away with hooks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the days will come on you when they will take you away with hooks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Returning to God represents submitting again to him. Alternate translation: “you have not submitted again to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have not returned to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of those who survived the plague and war as if they were a burning stick that someone pulled out of a fire. Alternate translation: “Some of you survived, like a burning stick that someone pulls out of a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You were like a burning stick snatched out of the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: God ruling over all the earth is spoken of as if he walks on the highest places of the earth. Alternate translation: “rules over all the earth” or “rules over even the highest places of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: treads on the high places of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “The virgin Israel” represents the nation of Israel. The nation of Israel being destroyed and having no other nation to help them become strong again is spoken of as if it were a young woman who has fallen and has no one to raise her up. Alternate translation: “The nation of Israel is like a woman who has fallen … no one to help her get up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The virgin Israel has fallen & no one to raise her up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Seek me” represents asking God for help. Alternate translation: “Ask me for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Seek me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “seek Bethel” represents going to Bethel to ask for help. Alternate translation: “Do not go to Bethel to ask for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not seek Bethel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “become nothing” represents being destroyed. Alternate translation: “Bethel will be completely destroyed” or “enemies will completely destroy Bethel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Bethel will become nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Seek Yahweh” represents asking him for help. Alternate translation: “Ask Yahweh for help” or “Ask me, Yahweh, for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Seek Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “it” refers to the fire, and “devour” represents destroying everything. God destroying everything is spoken of as if a fire were to destroy everything. Alternate translation: “It will destroy everything” or “He will destroy everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It will devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “a bitter thing” represents actions that harm people, and “turn justice into a bitter thing” represents harming people rather than doing for them what is just. Alternate translation: “say that they are doing what is just, but instead they harm people” or “refuse to do what is just and harm people instead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: turn justice into a bitter thing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents treating righteousness as if it were worthless. Alternate translation: “treat righteousness as though it were as unimportant as dirt” or “you despise what is righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: throw righteousness down to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God causing the sea water to fall on the earth as rain. Alternate translation: “he takes the waters of the sea and makes them rain down on the surface of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: calls for the waters & on the surface of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Seek good” represents choosing to do what good. “Good” and “evil” represent good actions and evil actions. Alternate translation: “Choose to do what is good and not what is evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Seek good and not evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “darkness” represents a time when disasters happen, and “light” represents a time when good things happen. Alternate translation: “It will be a time of darkness and disaster, not of light and blessing” or “On that day there will be disasters, not blessings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be darkness and not light

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the noise of songs as if it could be put somewhere else. It represents stopping singing. Alternate translation: “Stop singing your noisy songs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Remove from me the noise of your songs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to believe that Yahweh will cause disaster is spoken of as if the “day of disaster” were an object the people could put far from themselves. Alternate translation: “to those who refuse to believe that I will cause them to experience disaster” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to those who put off the day of disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: Distorting what is just is spoken of as if the leaders “turned justice into poison.” Alternate translation: “Yet you distort what is just” or “But you make laws that hurt innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yet you have turned justice into poison

contextId.occurrenceNote: Judging the people and determining they are wicked is spoken of as if the Israelites were a wall, and Yahweh determines the wall is not straight by using a plumb line. Alternate translation: “my people Israel are wicked. They are like a wall that is not straight up and down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put a plumb line among my people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: A land full of people that are unacceptable to God is spoken of as if the land were physically unclean. Here it means a land other than Israel. Alternate translation: “a foreign land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: an unclean land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Harming people is spoken of as if it were stomping on people. Alternate translation: “you who harm” or “you who oppress” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you who trample

contextId.occurrenceNote: Terrible and sad things happening during a day is spoken of as if the day had a bitter taste. Alternate translation: “everything that happens at that time will cause you great sorrow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a bitter day to its end

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a future time as if “days are coming.” Alternate translation: “there will be a time” or “in the future” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the days are coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refusing to give messages when the people want to hear from him is spoken of as if there would be a famine of his words. Alternate translation: “when I will cause something like a famine in the land … but for hearing the words of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when I will send a famine in the land & but for hearing the words of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing disaster is spoken of as disaster could overtake or meet someone. Alternate translation: “We will not experience disaster” or “Bad things will not happen to us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Disaster will not overtake or meet us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing the people of Israel to be great again is spoken of as if David’s kingdom were a tent that fell down and Yahweh will set it back up. Alternate translation: “David’s kingdom will be like tent that has fallen down, but I will raise it back up again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will raise up the tent of David that has fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: A future time is spoken of as if “days will come.” Alternate translation: “there will be a time … when the plowman” or “in the future … the plowman” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the days will come & when the plowman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bringing the people back to their land and keeping them safe from enemies is spoken of as if Israel were a plant that Yahweh would put in the ground and not let anyone pull the plant up from the ground. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to live in the land forever like a plant that is never uprooted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will plant them upon their land, and they will never again be uprooted from the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Damascus” represents the people of the city of Damascus. Alternate translation: “the people of Damascus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Damascus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Gilead” represents the people of the region of Gilead. Alternate translation: “the people of Gilead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Gilead

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Hazael’s descendants, who were rulers of the country where Damascus was located. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Hazael

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the ruler of that city or region. Alternate translation: “the ruler of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the man who holds the scepter in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Gaza” represents the people of the region of Gaza. Alternate translation: “the people of Gaza” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Gaza

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” represents the people of the country of Edom. Alternate translation: “the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the ruler of that city or region. Alternate translation: “the ruler” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the man who holds the scepter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents Yahweh’s power that he would use against Ekron. Alternate translation: “I will strike Ekron” or “I will destroy Ekron” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn my hand against Ekron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ekron” represents the people of the city of Ekron. Alternate translation: “the people of Ekron” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ekron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Tyre” represents the people of the city of Tyre. Alternate translation: “the people of Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” represents the people of the country of Edom. Alternate translation: “the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Moabite people. Alternate translation: “the people of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Moab” represents the people of Moab. Alternate translation: “The people of Moab will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab will die

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Israelite people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metonym for “run away without his weapons” or (2) this is meant literally as “run away wearing no clothes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: flee naked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the whole family” represents to the whole nation. The people of Israel were all descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “the whole nation” or “the whole clan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the whole family

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “families” represents nations or people groups. Alternate translation: “all the nations of the earth” or “all the clans on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the families of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “violence and destruction” represent things they have taken by being violent and destructive. Alternate translation: “They store up things that they have violently stolen from others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They store up violence and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob’s descendants. They were the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: People sinned against God by worshiping false gods at their altars. Here “punish the altars” represents punishing the people by destroying their altars. Alternate translation: “I will also destroy the altars at Bethel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will also punish the altars of Bethel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here having clean teeth represents having no food in the mouth to make the teeth dirty. Alternate translation: “I caused you to starve” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I gave you cleanness of teeth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving them “lack of bread” represents causing them to lack bread, and “bread” represents food in general. Alternate translation: “I caused you not to have enough food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: lack of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cities” represents the people of those cities. Alternate translation: “The people of two or three cities staggered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Two or three cities staggered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “afflicted you” represents afflicting their crops. Alternate translation: “I afflicted your crops with blight and mildew” or “I destroyed your crops with blight and mildew” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I afflicted you with blight and mildew

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sword” represents battle. God killed them by sending enemies to fight against them. Alternate translation: “I made your enemies kill your men in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I killed your young men with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of causing the enemies to steal their horses as if he carried the horses away. Alternate translation: “I made your enemies take away your horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: carried away your horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: A stench is a bad smell. The stench coming up to their nostrils represents them smelling something terrible. It can be stated clearly that the smell was from the dead bodies of those who were killed. Alternate translation: “I made you smell the terrible odor of the dead bodies in your camp” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: made the stench of your camp come up to your nostrils

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel’s descendants. Alternate translation: “you people of Israel” or “you Israelite people group” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Gilgal” represents the people of Gilgal, and going into captivity refers to being captured and taken away. Alternate translation: “For the people of Gilgal will surely be captured and taken away” or “For your enemies will surely capture the people of Gilgal and take them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For Gilgal will surely go into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym for the descendants of Joseph. Here it represents the northern kingdom of Israel, whose two largest tribes were the descendants of Joseph. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Joseph” or “Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “an evil time” represents a time when people are evil and do evil deeds. Alternate translation: “for it is a time when people are evil” or “for people do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for it is an evil time

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks as though the Israelites he is speaking to were part of the group that wandered in the wilderness. Alternate translation: “Did your ancestors bring” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Did you bring

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lifted up the images” represents worshiping them. Alternate translation: “You have worshiped the images of Sikkuth … and Kaiwan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: You have lifted up the images of Sikkuth & and Kaiwan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel’s descendants. Alternate translation: “the Israelites come” or “the Israelite people group comes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel comes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” is a metonym that represents reign or rule. The people doing evil things, which causes Yahweh to bring disaster on them, is spoken of as if they were causing “violence” to rule them. Alternate translation: “but who are actually causing me to send violent people to destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: and make the throne of violence come near

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Joseph” represents his descendants. Alternate translation: “they do not grieve about the descendants of Joseph whom enemies will soon destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they do not grieve over the ruin of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents his descendants. Alternate translation: “I hate the descendants of Jacob because they have become arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I detest the pride of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Lebo Hamath” represents the northern border of Israel, and “brook of the Arabah” represents the southern border. Alternate translation: “from the northern border of your nation to the southern border” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from Lebo Hamath to the brook of the Arabah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents his descendants the Israelites. Alternate translation: “how will we Israelites survive? We are so small and weak!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: how will Jacob survive? For he is so small.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents an army. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will send an army to attack the house of Jeroboam, and the army will destroy the high places of Isaac and the sanctuaries of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The high places of Isaac will be destroyed, the sanctuaries of Israel will be ruined, and I will rise against the house of Jeroboam with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these represent the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Isaac … the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Isaac & Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents “people.” Alternate translation: “Amos is right here among the Israelites, and he is planning to do bad things to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Amos has conspired against you in the middle of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents “people.” Disrupting the peace is spoken of as if Amos’s words were a heavy object that the land could not carry. Alternate translation: “What his is saying disturb the peace among the people” or “His message will cause trouble among the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The land cannot bear all his words

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the enemies. Alternate translation: “Enemies will kill Jeroboam” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeroboam will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the family or descendants of Isaac. Alternate translation: “do not speak against the descendants of Isaac” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: do not speak against the house of Isaac

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents enemies. Alternate translation: “enemies will kill your sons and daughters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your sons and your daughters will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pride of Jacob” is a title for Yahweh. Also “Jacob” represents his descendants, the Israelites. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has sworn by himself, saying” or “Yahweh, of whom the Israelites are so proud, has sworn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has sworn by the pride of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sin” represents the false god the people worship in Samaria. Alternate translation: “by the false god of Samaria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sin of Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents an army attacking with their weapons. Alternate translation: “I will send an enemy army to kill the rest of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will kill the last of them with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “I will pull them up from there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there my hand will take them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents their enemies. Alternate translation: “there I will cause their enemies to kill them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there will I give orders to the sword, and it will kill them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents seeing. The phrase “keep my eyes on them” is an idiom that means to watch closely. Alternate translation: “I will watch closely and make sure only bad things happen to them and not good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will keep my eyes on them for harm and not for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are probably the steps that ancient people imagined led up to God’s palace in the heavens. However, some modern versions wish to read a different Hebrew word meaning “palace” or “rooms.” Here “his steps” probably is a metonym for God’s palace. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he who builds his steps in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents seeing. Also, Yahweh speaks of himself in third person. Alternate translation: “I, the Lord Yahweh, see that the people of this kingdom are very sinful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the eyes of the Lord Yahweh are on the sinful kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents a family. And, “Jacob” represents his descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents their enemies. Alternate translation: “Enemies will kill all the sinners of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: All the sinners of my people will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. The idiom “called by my name” means they once belonged to Yahweh. This means that in the past the people had conquered and taken control of these territories. Alternate translation: “all the nations that once belonged to me” or “all the nations that I caused the people of Israel to conquer in the past” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all the nations that are called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. Together they emphasize that Yahweh shouts loudly as he prepares to judge the nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will roar from Zion; he will raise his voice from Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize his continued anger. The abstract nouns “anger” and “wrath” can be translated using the adjectives “angry” and “furious.” Alternate translation: “He was continually angry and always furious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: His anger raged continually, and his wrath lasted forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the enemy will capture the people like people catch fish. Alternate translation: “they will capture you as people capture animals, and they take you away” or “they will defeat you and cruelly force you to go away with them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will take you away with hooks, the last of you with fishhooks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. The contrast between “the big house” and “the little house” means that this refers to all houses. Alternate translation: “all the houses will be smashed into small pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the big house will be smashed to pieces, and the little house to bits

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means basically the same thing as the first part of the sentence. Distorting what is right is spoken of as if righteousness were a sweet fruit that the people made bitter tasting. Alternate translation: “you distort what is right” or “you punish those who do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fruit of righteousness into bitterness

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing. The huge amount of grapes and wine in Israel is spoken of as if wine flows down the hills and mountains. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The mountains will drip sweet wine, and all the hills will flow with it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to the city of Samaria. Cities were often spoken of as if they were women. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: see what great confusion is in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the houses being destroyed as if they were alive and would die. Alternate translation: “The houses of ivory will be destroyed” or “The houses of ivory will collapse” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The houses of ivory will perish

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Amos uses the questions in verses 3-6 to present examples of things that people already know about what causes things to happen and what are the results of things that happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what must happen in order for two people to walk together. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Two people will walk together only if they have first agreed to walk together.” or “You know that two people will walk together only if they have agreed to do that.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will two walk together unless they have agreed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what causes a lion to roar. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A lion will roar in the forest only when he has a victim.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will a lion roar in the forest when he has no victim?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what causes a lion to growl. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A young lion will growl from his den only if he has caught something.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will a young lion growl from his den if he has caught nothing?

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Amos uses the questions in verses 3-6 to present examples of things that people already know about what causes things to happen and what are the results of things that happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what causes a bird to fall into a trap. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A bird can fall into a trap on the ground only when bait has been set for him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Can a bird fall in a trap on the ground when no bait is set for him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what causes a trap to spring up. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “A trap will spring up from the ground only when it has caught something.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will a trap spring up from the ground when it has not caught anything?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what they already know about what happens when a trumpet sounds. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “When the trumpet sounds in the city, the people will tremble.” or “When the trumpet sounds in the city, we expect that people will tremble.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: If a trumpet sounds in a city, will the people not tremble?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind the people of what they should already know about what causes a disaster. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “If disaster overtakes a city, Yahweh has sent it.” or “If disaster overtakes a city, we know that Yahweh has sent it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: If disaster overtakes a city, has Yahweh not sent it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to remind people of what people do when a lion roars. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The lion has roared; so we know that everyone will be afraid.” or “The lion has roared; so of course everyone will be afraid.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: The lion has roared; who will not fear?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses this question to emphasize what people should already know about what prophets do when God speaks. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The Lord Yahweh has spoken; so we know that the prophets will prophesy.” or “The Lord Yahweh has spoken; so of course the prophets will prophesy.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh has spoken; who will not prophesy?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to rebuke the people for saying that they want the day of Yahweh to be soon. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You long for the day of Yahweh.” or “You should not long for the day of Yahweh!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you long for the day of Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question emphasizes that bad things will happen then. It can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “The day of Yahweh will certainly be darkness and not light!” or “Bad things, not good things, will certainly happen on the day of Yahweh!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will not the day of Yahweh be darkness and not light?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “Will not the day of Yahweh be” is understood from the previous sentence. Like the previous question, it emphasizes that terrible things, not good things, will happen on the day of Yahweh. It can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “It will be a time of when terrible things, not good things, will happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Gloom and no brightness?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) God uses this question to rebuke them because they did not offer sacrifices. Alternate translation: “You did not bring me sacrifices … Israel.” or (2) God uses this question to remind them that the sacrifices were not the most important part about their relationship. Alternate translation: “You did not have to bring me sacrifices … Israel.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Did you bring me sacrifices & Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The notable men use this question to emphasize that the kingdoms of Israel and Judah are better than those other kingdoms. Alternate translation: “Your two kingdoms are better than they are.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are they better than your two kingdoms?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The notable men use this question to emphasize that their kingdoms are larger than those other kingdoms. Alternate translation: “Their border is smaller than yours.” or “Those countries are smaller than Judah and Samaria.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is their border larger than your border?

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is impossible for a horse to run on rocky cliffs without getting hurt. Amos uses this rhetorical question to rebuke them for their actions. Alternate translation: “Horses do not run on rocky cliffs.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do horses run on the rocky cliffs?

contextId.occurrenceNote: One does not plow on rocky ground. Amos uses this rhetorical question to rebuke them for their actions. Alternate translation: “A person does not plow with oxen on rocky ground.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Does one plow there with oxen?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use a question to emphasize that they believe they captured a city because of their own power. Alternate translation: “We captured Karnaim by our own power!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have we not taken Karnaim by our own strength?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to teach Amos. Alternate translation: “tell me what you see.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what do you see?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to teach Amos. Alternate translation: “Tell me what you see, Amos.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What do you see, Amos?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The merchants use theses question to emphasize that want to start selling their items again. This can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “They are always asking when the new moon will be over or when the Sabbath will be over so that can sell their grain and wheat again.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: They say, “When will the new moon be over, so we can sell grain again? When will the Sabbath day be over, so that we can sell wheat?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos uses a question to emphasize that these things will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause the land to shake, and every one who lives in it will mourn.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will not the land quake for this, and every one who lives in it mourn?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that the people of Israel are no more special to him than the people of Cush, the Philistines, and the Arameans. Alternate translation: “You people of Israel, you are certainly no more important to me than the people of Cush—this … declaration—I brought up Israel … the Philistines … the Arameans from Kir.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you not like the people of Cush to me, & Israel—this & declaration—did I not bring up Israel & the Philistines & the Arameans from Kir?

contextId.occurrenceNote: How the people of Israel treated the poor is compared to how people step heavily on the ground (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They trample on the heads of the poor as people trample on dust on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his judgment on the people of Israel to crushing them with something very heavy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will crush you as a cart that is full of grain can crush someone

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Lord compares the people of Israel being rescued with an unsuccessful attempt to rescue an animal from a lion. They will not be completely rescued. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As the shepherd rescues & so will the people of Israel & be rescued

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “break out like a fire” represents destroying things as fire destroys things. Alternate translation: “he will become like a fire that breaks out suddenly and destroys everything” or “he will destroy everything like a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: he will break out like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents causing there to be much justice and righteous. Alternate translation: “let there be so much justice that it is like flowing water, and let there be so much righteousness that it is like a constantly flowing stream” or “let justice abound like a flood, and let righteousness abound like a stream that never stops” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: let justice flow like water, and righteousness like a constantly flowing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amos compares the rising and sinking of the waters of the Nile River to how Yahweh will cause the land to shake when he judges the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: All of it will rise up like the Nile River & like the river of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the River” and “river of Egypt” both refer to the Nile river. Yahweh causing the land to shake violently is compared to the waters of the Nile river rising and sinking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: all of it will rise up like the River, and sink again like the river of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The picture here is of grain falling through the sieve and stones being kept out. The idea is that Yahweh will remove all of the sinful people from Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will shake the house of Israel & as one shakes grain in a sieve, so that not the smallest stone will fall to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “foundations” represents the whole temple. Alternate translation: “so that the whole temple will shake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: so that the foundations will shake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heads” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “Break the pillars so that the temple falls on all of the people and kills them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Break them in pieces on all of their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: this is Yahweh’s declaration

contextId.occurrenceNote: God says this to warn the people of Israel that he will judge them. Alternate translation: “prepare to meet me, your God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: prepare to meet your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear whether Amos is speaking about God, or God is speaking about himself. If God is speaking about himself, it can be translated with the words “I” and “me.” Alternate translation: “I who form the mountains … reveal my thoughts … is my name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: he who forms the mountains & reveals his thoughts & is his name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “words from me, Yahweh” or “my messages” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: the words of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **captivity**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “capture.” This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Their enemies will capture their king and take him away as a prisoner” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Their king will go into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “oppression is in her” refers to leaders in Samaria oppressing the people. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **oppress**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “oppress” or “cause to suffer.” Alternate translation: “how the leaders oppress people” or “and how they cause people to suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: what oppression is in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **destruction**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “destroy.” The phrase “the strong” refers to strong people, specifically soldiers. Alternate translation: “He suddenly destroys the strong people” or “He suddenly destroys the soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: He brings sudden destruction on the strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **destruction**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “destroy.” Alternate translation: “so that the fortresses are destroyed” or “and he destroys the fortresses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: so that destruction comes on the fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “These are the things concerning Israel that God revealed to Amos, one of the shepherds in Tekoa” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the things concerning Israel that Amos, one of the shepherds in Tekoa, received in revelation

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God gave him these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: He received these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who they made to pay a penalty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: those who were fined

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to emphasize what he has said. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You people of Israel certainly know that what I have said is true!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not so, people of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Your enemies will cut off the horns of the altars, and the horns will fall to the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The horns of the altar will be cut off and fall to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they will throw you out toward Harmon” or “your enemies will force you to leave the city and go toward Harmon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be thrown out toward Harmon

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The phrase “One piece of land” represents any piece of land.” Alternate translation: “It rained on one piece of land” or “It rained on some pieces of land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: One piece of land was rained on

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People have forsaken her” or “they have abandoned her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: she is forsaken on her land

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the enemy will smash the big house to pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the big house will be smashed to pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “other people will take your land and divide it up among themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: your land will be measured and divided up

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Though enemies capture them and force them to go to a foreign land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Though they go into captivity, driven by their enemies before them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will ever again uproot them from the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will never again be uprooted from the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrases “the shepherd” and “the lion” refer to any shepherd or lion. Alternate translation: “As a shepherd … a lion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: As the shepherd & the lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Some of the wealthy people had two houses: one that they lived in during the winter and one that they lived in during the summer. This refers to any winter and summer houses. Alternate translation: “the houses they live in during the winter and the houses they live in during the summer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: the winter house with the summer house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to any piece of land where it did not rain. Alternate translation: “the pieces of land where it did not rain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: the piece of land where it did not rain

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to any cities that sent out large numbers of soldiers. Alternate translation: “Cities that went out with a thousand … cities that went out with a hundred” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: The city that went out with a thousand & the one that went out with a hundred

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In 6:9-10 Amos describes a hypothetical situation of what it will be like when Yahweh hands the people of Israel over to their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to innocent people in general. Alternate translation: “innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the innocent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to needy people in general. Alternate translation: “needy people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to poor people in general. Alternate translation: “poor people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to oppressed people in general. Alternate translation: “oppressed people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the oppressed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These adjectives refer to people in general. Alternate translation: “Swift people … strong people … mighty people” or “The strong person … the strong person … the mighty person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: The swift & the strong & the mighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the poor” refers to poor people. Alternate translation: “you who oppress poor people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: you who oppress the poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “just” is a nominal adjective that refers to just people. Alternate translation: “just people” or “righteous people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the just

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “needy” is a nominal adjective that refers to people who are in need. Alternate translation: “people in need” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the needy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the nominal adjectives “the needy” and “the poor.” Alternate translation: “you who trample those who are in need and remove those in the land that are poor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: you who trample the needy and remove the poor of the land

index.name: Making Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information Explicit
Singular Pronouns that refer to Groups
